entry.title: Building a Lightweight Remote Gradio MCP Server with DuckDuckGo Search
entry.summary:
Gradio now lets you spin up an MCP (Machine Control Plane) server with almost no boilerplate, so I decided to give it a try. https://www.gradio.app/guides/building-mcp-server-with-gradio Running everything locally worked greatâ€”but because Gradio lives in the Hugging Face ecosystem, I wondered if I could deploy the exact same code to a Space and treat it as a lightweight remote MCP server. Spoiler: you can! uv init gradio-mcp-server cd gradio-mcp-server
uv is the Rust-powered Python package/build tool from Astral. (Any env manager works; uv just makes everything reproducible.) uv add "gradio[mcp]" duckduckgo-search
The [mcp] extra pulls in the small Gradio extension that exposes the MCP interface. Building an MCP server is identical to making a regular Gradio appâ€”the only difference is paâ€¦

entry.title: Get Emojis via Command Line
entry.summary:
ðŸš€ A command with autocomplete made with C++.
Today was pretty calm, so I spent some time tinkering with ideas. Among them, I found a link to a bunch of emojis in my bookmarks and thought: â€” Why not fetch these emojis via the command line to make things easier?! So I started writing some basic code and came up with this simple command to help out, even if just in a basic way. See how to compile and install it on your Unix-like system. Of course, youâ€™ll need either GCC or Clang installed. Then just follow these steps: Using wget: wget -q bit.ly/emoji-txt -O ~/.emojis.txt
Or using cURL: curl -sL bit.ly/emoji-txt -o ~/.emojis.txt
C++ file:
Example: vim emoji.cpp Paste this code inside: #include <iostream> #include <fstream>
constexpr auto show_emoji = [](const std::string& query){ â€¦

entry.title: A beginner's guide to the Ltx-Video-0.9.7 model by Lightricks on Replicate
entry.summary: This is a simplified guide to an AI model called Ltx-Video-0.9.7 maintained by Lightricks. If you like these kinds of analysis, you should join AImodels.fyi or follow us on Twitter. The first DiT-based video generation model capable of real-time performance, ltx-video-0.9.7 produces high-quality 30 FPS videos at 1216Ã—704 resolution. Created by lightricks, this model represents a breakthrough in speed and quality for AI video generation. Like ltx-video, it supports text-to-video and image-to-video generation with exceptional temporal consistency. The model takes text prompts or images as input and generates fluid video sequences that maintain coherence across frames. It features specialized capabilities for keyframe-based animation, video extension in both directions, and video-to-video transformations. Text Prompts: Detailed descriptions of desired video scenes and actions Images: Reference images for video generation Frame Settings: Number of frames (must be 8N+1), resolution (multiples of 32) Parameters: Guidance scale (3-3.5 recommended), inference steps (20-50) Video Clips: 30 FPS sequences at 1216Ã—704 resolution Format: Compatible with standard video formats Length: Variable frame counts based on 8N+1 formula The model excels at generating photorea... Click here to read the full guide to Ltx-Video-0.9.7

entry.title: Quantum Financial System vs. Traditional Banking: A Comparative Analysis
entry.summary: The Quantum Financial System represents a paradigm shift from traditional banking methods, offering enhanced security, speed, and transparency. Security Enhancements Traditional banking systems are vulnerable to cyberattacks due to reliance on classical encryption. In contrast, the QFS employs quantum cryptography, providing a level of security that is currently unattainable by conventional means. Transaction Efficiency While traditional banks often experience delays due to intermediaries and batch processing, the QFS enables near-instantaneous transactions through quantum computing capabilities, significantly improving user experience. Transparency and Trust The QFS's decentralized nature ensures that all transactions are recorded on an immutable ledger, promoting transparency and reducing the potential for fraud. This contrasts with traditional banking, where centralized control can obscure transaction histories.

entry.title: Daily Debug â€” Day 1: Blocks in Motion
entry.summary:
âœ… What I Got Done Today
ðŸ“¦ Completed 4 modules in Blender â€” continuing to build muscle memory with modeling tools and interface flow. Already feeling more confident navigating the workspace. ðŸŽ¬ Started building a one-shot in Unreal Engine called The Overture Pact â€” early concept work, scene blocking, and thinking through tone and mechanics. Feels cinematic and story-driven. ðŸŽ® Kicked off a mini-game in Godot called NumberFall â€” a simple, falling-number mechanic for now, but a great way to practice core Godot features and UI work. Working across three engines sounds chaotic, but it wasnâ€™tâ€”each served a different creative purpose: Blender for design and visuals Unreal for immersive storytelling Godot for gameplay testing and prototyping Thatâ€™s the rhythm I want to cultivate: let each tool serve its unique purpose instead of trying to force a â€œone-size-fits-allâ€ workflow. Finish one more Blender module (possibly start texturing) Flesh out player input in NumberFall
Document world/plot for The Overture Pact
Bonus: string swap on both guitars if time permits Today felt modular in the best way. Not everything needs to be polished or finalâ€”what matters is that pieces are moving. As long as I keep shipping small things and logging what I learn, the bigger picture builds itself. One mechanic. One asset. One idea at a time.

entry.title: Beginner-Friendly Guide to Solving "Distribute Candies Among Children II" | LeetCode 2929 Explained (C++ | JavaScript | Python)
entry.summary:
Distributing candies among children sounds simple, right? But what if thereâ€™s a limit on how many candies each child can get? Letâ€™s break down this classic combinatorial problem and solve it efficiently! You are given two positive integers: n = total candies limit = maximum candies any child can receive Goal: Find the total number of ways to distribute n candies among 3 children such that no child gets more than limit candies. Input: n = 5, limit = 2 Output: 3 Explanation: Valid distributions are (1, 2, 2), (2, 1, 2), and (2, 2, 1). Without any limit, the problem reduces to distributing n identical candies into 3 children (bins), which can be done in: Total ways = C(n + 3 - 1, 3 - 1) = C(n + 2, 2)
Here, C(a, b) is the binomial coefficient "a choose b". This formula comes from the Stars anâ€¦

entry.title: Mi primer post en DEV.to: AsÃ­ lleguÃ© a la plataforma
entry.summary:
Nunca habÃ­a publicado contenido ni participado en redes sociales; sin embargo, a raÃ­z de mi inscripciÃ³n en el hackathon de Bolt (https://hackathon.dev/), recibÃ­ una suscripciÃ³n gratuita a DEV.to ++. Esta es mi primera publicaciÃ³n, y quiero explicarles brevemente por quÃ© decidÃ­ unirme y quÃ© espero lograr aquÃ­. Ayer completÃ© mi registro en el hackatÃ³n de Bolt, cuyo objetivo es desarrollar soluciones innovadoras usando inteligencia artificial. Uno de los beneficios de inscribirse fue el acceso a DEV.to ++ sin costo. Siendo estudiante de IngenierÃ­a InformÃ¡tica, siempre habÃ­a escuchado hablar de DEV.to como un sitio de referencia para desarrolladores, pero nunca habÃ­a entrado porque no me considero un usuario activo de redes ni un autor frecuente de contenido. Compartir aprendizajes prÃ¡cticos:
Construir reputaciÃ³n profesional:
Conectar con otros desarrolladores y competencias:
Primeras metas en DEV.to
Explicar mi experiencia en el hackatÃ³n de Bolt: DetallarÃ© el proceso de registro, los retos iniciales al adaptarme al equipo y las dinÃ¡micas de trabajo bajo presiÃ³n.
Solicitar retroalimentaciÃ³n en fase temprana: PublicarÃ© dudas o bloqueos que encuentre, esperando que otros miembros de la comunidad aporten soluciones o enfoques alternativos.
Este es mi primer paso en DEV.to. Agradezco de antemano cualquier comentario, crÃ­tica o sugerencia que puedan brindarme. Planeo publicar regularmente mis experiencias en hackatones y metodologÃ­as Ã¡giles para que sean Ãºtiles a otros estudiantes e ingenieros que, al igual que yo, prefieren enfocarse en el cÃ³digo antes que en las redes sociales. Si has participado en algÃºn hackatÃ³n reciente o tienes consejos sobre cÃ³mo maximizar el uso de DEV.to ++, te invito a dejar tu feedback. Â¡Nos vemos en los prÃ³ximos artÃ­culos!

entry.title: 2929. Distribute Candies Among Children II
entry.summary: 2929. Distribute Candies Among Children II Difficulty: Medium Topics: Math, Combinatorics, Enumeration You are given two positive integers n and limit. Return the total number of ways to distribute n candies among 3 children such that no child gets more than limit candies. Example 1: Input: n = 5, limit = 2 Output: 3 Explanation: There are 3 ways to distribute 5 candies such that no child gets more than 2 candies: (1, 2, 2), (2, 1, 2) and (2, 2, 1). Example 2: Input: n = 3, limit = 3 Output: 10 Explanation: There are 10 ways to distribute 3 candies such that no child gets more than 3 candies: (0, 0, 3), (0, 1, 2), (0, 2, 1), (0, 3, 0), (1, 0, 2), (1, 1, 1), (1, 2, 0), (2, 0, 1), (2, 1, 0) and (3, 0, 0). Constraints: 1 <= n <= 106 1 <= limit <= 106 Hint: We can enumerate the number of candiâ€¦

entry.title: Meta Shifts to AI for Product Risk Reviews
entry.summary: Meta is moving to automate the majority of its internal risk assessments using artificial intelligence. Until now, most updates to Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp underwent manual reviews to ensure they would not harm users or violate laws. That is about to change. According to a report published by TechCrunch, Meta plans to have AI handle up to 90 percent of these assessments. The company says this will speed up product development while still keeping humans in the loop for sensitive or unfamiliar issues. This shift is part of a wider push inside Meta to cut costs and streamline decision making across its platforms. Engineers will soon be asked to input risk-related information into a system that scores each update and determines whether human review is needed. If not, the feature could go live automatically. Critics argue that AI cannot yet fully understand complex social or political risks, especially those tied to misinformation, privacy, or cultural harm. Metaâ€™s executives have acknowledged that risk automation will be a gradual process, and that human judgment will remain essential for edge cases. Full story: https://techcrunch.com/2025/05/31/meta-plans-to-automate-many-of-its-product-risk-assessments/ Alternate source: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/artificial-intelligence/meta-to-handover-most-of-product-risk-assessments-to-ai/articleshow/121541117.cms
